z:row.TitlePrimary: Plasma source ion implantation: history, successes, failures, challenges, and future prospects
z:row.TitleSecondary: International Conference on Plasma Science (papers in summary form only received), 5-8 June 1995
z:row.TitleTertiary: IEEE Conference Record - Abstracts. 1995 IEEE International Conference on Plasma Science (Cat. No.95CH35796)
z:row.Keyword: ion implantation|ion sources|plasma applications|plasma production|plasma sheaths|semiconductor technology
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Summary form only given, as follows. Plasma Source Ion Implantation (PSII) represents a radical departure from conventional ion implantation technology. PSII circumvents the line of sight restriction inherent in conventional ion implantation. In PSII, targets to be implanted are placed directly in a plasma source and then pulse-biased to a high negative potential. A plasma ion matrix sheath forms around the target and ions bombard the entire target compared with conventional ion implantation, PSII minimizes the problems of shadowing and excessive sputtering of the target material, which can severely limit the retained dose of the implanted ion species. Uniformity can be achieved in a batch processing mode. The author presents: a historical overview of the development of PSII, a brief review of PSII physics and technology, a summary of world-wide PSII activities, a discussion of laboratory and industrial field test results with PSII, recent developments leading to scale-up and commercialization of PSII, recent extensions of PSII technology to semiconductor processing, and an assessment of future prospects for commercial development of PSII
z:row.User2: plasma source ion implantation; future prospects; history; successes; failures; challenges; ion implantation technology; targets; plasma source; pulse-biased targets; negative potential; plasma ion matrix sheath; excessive sputtering; shadowing; implanted ion species; batch processing mode; historical overview; review; test results; semiconductor processing

z:row.TitlePrimary: Comprehensive modeling of plasma source ion implantation
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings of the 1995 27th International SAMPE Technical Conference, Oct 9-12 1995
z:row.Keyword: Ion implantation|Computer simulation|Plasma sources|Diffusion|Physics|Nitrogen|Titanium alloys|Dosimetry|Tribology
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: As a critical step towards the development of a comprehensive model for plasma source ion implantation which will eventually include modules for the chamber and pulse modulator, plasma, implantation, diffusion, and materials physics such as hardness, the plasma and implantation modules have been linked. Presented are comparisons of the model to measured retained dose profiles for various ratios of applied bias rise time to total bias pulse time ratios which translate into various average energies of the impacting ion energy distribution for a paradigm case of nitrogen implantation into titanium or closely related alloys. Even though a best fit with a 20% drop in this average ion energy is obtained, a very low sensitivity of the above mentioned rise time ratio relative to the retained dose is observed. Precise modeling of the impacting ion energy distribution with many variables accounted for seems computationally inefficient for most cases. Simplified models for the plasma are suggested.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Plasma source ion implantation; Pulse modulator; Materials physics; Applied bias rise time; Total bias pulse time; Nitrogen implantation; Ion energy distribution

z:row.TitlePrimary: Target temperature prediction for plasma source ion implantation
z:row.TitleSecondary: First International Workshop on Plasma-Based Ion Implantation, 4-6 Aug. 1993
z:row.TitleTertiary: J. Vac. Sci. Technol. B, Microelectron. Nanometer Struct. (USA)
z:row.Keyword: ion implantation|plasma applications
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Vacuum Science & Technology B (Microelectronics and Nanometer Structures)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Plasma source ion implantation (PSII) is a plasma-based ion implantation technique which requires pulsed operation. Because the power incident on the implanted objects (targets) can be large, target temperatures can be quite high. Therefore, target temperature prediction can be quite useful, both in reaching high temperatures when they are desirable, and in avoiding high temperatures when they are undesirable. In this paper, a simple, time-dependent, lumped-capacity thermal model is developed for predicting temperatures in PSII targets. Two simple analytical models are used to justify the assumptions used in developing the lumped model. Comparison of the model with measured target temperatures is used to validate the assumptions of the model. The comparison is favorable
z:row.User2: plasma source ion implantation; pulsed operation; target temperature; time-dependent lumped-capacity thermal model; PSII targets

z:row.TitlePrimary: Finite element simulation of the hardness testing of ion-implanted materials
z:row.Keyword: Hardness testing|Ion implantation|Finite element method|Corrosion
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Applied Mechanics, Transactions ASME
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Ion implantation has been shown to be an effective process for improving the wear, corrosion, and fatigue properties of metals. Characterization of surfaces which have been altered by ion implantation is difficult, because the properties vary with depth from the surface and because the affected material is at extremely shallow depths (on the order of 0.1 microns). Hardness testing provides a simple method for assessing the effectiveness of ion-implantation in improving certain properties of a metal. It provides information about increased strength near the surface, indicating possible improvements in wear resistance and/or corrosion resistance. The interpretation of such test, though, is complicated by the fact that the properties of ion-implanted materials vary with depth from the surface. Finite simulation can enhance the understanding of hardness tests in surface-modified materials by providing a link between the results of the test and the actual changes induced by the implantation.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Surface-modified materials; Ion-implanted materials; Large-strain-plastic deformation; Ion-implanted surface hardness distribution

z:row.TitlePrimary: LOTOS in Alcatel
z:row.TitleSecondary: Fifth International Conference on Formal Description Techniques for Distributed Systems and Communications Protocols - FORTE '92. IFIP TC6/WG6.1, 13-16 Oct. 1992
z:row.Keyword: asynchronous transfer mode|knowledge acquisition|specification languages
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Alcatel Austria, ELIN Res. Centre, Wien, Austria
z:row.Abstract: Summarizes the work on LOTOS within Alcatel and sketches the plan for transferring this technology from research to development units. Knowledge acquisition and basic research was performed in the scope of European research projects. The preliminary results of these projects and the capabilities of the technique itself were assessed in an internal experiment where parts of the call control software of an ATM switch have been respecified. This experiment has led to promising results. The next step was therefore to set up a plan for technology transfer to development units. This plan assigns a phase-wise approach. First a pilot use with a small team, only for specification of telecommunication protocols and services at system analysis level, later on broadening to system design and implementation
z:row.User2: knowledge acquisition; telecommunication services; protocol specification; SDL; LOTOS; Alcatel; European research projects; call control software; ATM switch; technology transfer; development units; telecommunication protocols; system analysis; system design

z:row.TitlePrimary: Study of the relationship between wear rate and nitrogen concentration profile and application to plasma source ion implanted Ti-6Al-4V alloy
z:row.Keyword: Wear of materials|Titanium alloys|Aluminum alloys|Vanadium alloys|Radiation effects|Ion implantation|Nitrogen|Mechanical testing|Surface measurement|Thermal effects|Wear resistance|Dosimetry|Composition effects
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Nitrogen implantation by plasma source ion implantation was conducted on Ti-6Al-4V alloy. The wear performance was characterized using a pin-on-disk wear tester and an alpha-step profilometer. Nitrogen concentration depth profiles of implanted samples were studied using a scanning Auger microprobe. It is found that the lowest wear rate in the implanted zone corresponds to the nitrogen concentration peak. By varying the target temperature, the nitrogen concentration profile was engineered to achieve a better wear behavior. The pin-on-disk wear data agree with the expected result.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Titanium aluminum vanadium alloys; Plasma source ion implantation; Pin on disk wear testing; Alpha step profilometer; Scanning Auger microprobe

z:row.TitlePrimary: The relationship between depth profiles of nitrogen concentration, hardness, and wear rate in ion-implanted Ti-6Al-4V
z:row.TitleTertiary: Nucl. Instrum. Methods Phys. Res. B, Beam Interact. Mater. At. (Netherlands)
z:row.Keyword: aluminium alloys|hardness|ion implantation|nitrogen|titanium alloys|vanadium alloys|wear|yield stress
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Nuclear Instruments & Methods in Physics Research, Section B (Beam Interactions with Materials and Atoms)
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin-Madison Univ., WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The property changes induced by nitrogen ion implantation of Ti-6Al-4V alloys are considered, with emphasis on the effects of the nitrogen concentration profiles on hardness and wear rate. The comparison of the measured hardness profile to the profile from a finite element simulation reinforces the assumption that nitride formation, rather than damage, is the primary hardening mechanism. In addition, these techniques allow determination of the increase in the yield stress caused by the ion implantation. In this case, a ten-fold increase in the yield stress is found. Wear rate profiles are compared to the nitrogen concentration profile and are found to be low at depths greater than the nitrogen profile depth. This is assumed to occur because of the geometry of the wear test device
z:row.User2: depth profiles; hardness; wear rate; ion-implanted Ti-6Al-4V; property changes; concentration profiles; finite element simulation; nitride formation; primary hardening mechanism; yield stress; wear test device; Ti-Al-V:N

z:row.TitlePrimary: Wear improvement evaluation of non-homogeneous surface modified materials
z:row.Keyword: Wear of materials|Tribology|Ion implantation
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Quantitative evaluation of the improvement of wear properties due to surface modification is complicated by the fact that these properties vary as the modified layer is penetrated. Different methods of evaluation of the same wear test results can yield different or even contrary conclusions. In order to evaluate wear behavior correctly, a wear model that accounts for depth-dependent wear rates is developed and applied to four typical wear tests. It is found that under fixed wear test conditions, the evaluation of wear in surface modified materials depends markedly on the final depth of penetration. This is in contrast to the case of homogeneous materials, where the comparison of the wear behaviour of different materials is largely independent of wear depth. An improvement factor is introduced as the basic quantity for evaluating the wear improvement provided by surface modification. The prediction of the improvement factor from a basic tribology test is carried out for nitrogen ion-implanted Ti-6A1-4V specimens.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Wear properties; Surface modifications

z:row.TitlePrimary: Three-dimensional analysis of SiC/SiC composite structures for fusion reactors
z:row.Keyword: Tokamak devices|Laminated composites|Finite element method|Three dimensional|Silicon carbide|Thermal load
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The structural analysis of a SiC/SiC composite first wall in a tokamak fusion reactor is explored using the finite element method. The analysis is done in three dimensions under thermal and pressure loads. The effect of the three-dimensional analysis on the results is compared with that for the two-dimensional analysis. The comparison indicates that for laminated SiC/SiC composite structures, the two-dimensional analysis, which ignores the effect of the stacking sequence of the laminate and the effect of the interlaminar shear stress, is insufficient for reactor design.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Pressure loads; Interlaminar shear stress; Reactor design; Stacking sequence; ARIES-I tokamak fusion reactor

z:row.TitlePrimary: Safety and environmental characteristics of recent D-3He and DT tokamak power reactors
z:row.TitleSecondary: Tenth Topical Meeting on the Technology of Fusion Energy, 7-11 June 1992
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor safety
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Inst., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A comparison of the key features of the D-3He Apollo and the DT Aries fusion power reactor designs is made. The reduction in neutron production from the D-3He reaction has a major effect on the performance of Tokamak reactors. One of the biggest impacts is the low radiation damage rate in D-3He systems which allows a permanent first wall to be utilized. The reduction in radioactivity in D-3He reactors has a particularly advantageous effect on the storage of wastes as well as on the safety to the public in the event of the worst conceivable accident. The more difficult D-3He physics requirements are offset by the technological advantages of using this fuel in place of the DT cycle
z:row.User2: environmental characteristics; Apollo; Aries fusion power reactor; neutron production; Tokamak reactors; radiation damage rate

z:row.AuthorPrimary: Kulcinski,G.L.|Blanchard,James, P.|El-Guebaly,Laila, A.|Emmert,Gilbert, A.|Khater,Hesham, Y.|Maynard,Charles, W.|Mogahed,E.A.|Santarius,John, F.|Sawan,Mohamed, E.|Sviatoslavsky,I.N.|Wittenberg,L.J.
z:row.TitlePrimary: Summary of Apollo, a D-3He tokamak reactor design
z:row.Keyword: Tokamak Devices -- Design|Helium|Direct Energy Conversion|Thermoelectric Energy Conversion|Nuclear Reactors, Fusion - Environmental Impact
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The key features of Apollo, a conceptual D-3He tokamak reactor for commercial electricity production, are summarized. The 1000-MW(electric) design utilizes direct conversion of synchrotron radiation power and thermal conversion of transport, neutron, and bremsstrahlung radiation power. The direct conversion method uses rectennas, and the thermal conversion cycle uses an organic coolant. Apollo operates in the first-stability regime, with a major radius of 7.89 m, a peak magnetic field on the toroidal field coils of 19.3 T, a 53-MA plasma current, and a 6.7% beta value. The low neutron production of the D-3He fuel cycle greatly reduces the radiation damage rate and allows a full-lifetime first wall and structure made of standard steels with only slight modifications to reduce activation levels. The reduced radioactive inventory and afterheat give significant safety and environmental advantages over deuterium-tritium reactors.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Apollo Tokamak Reactor; Rectannas; Organic Coolant

z:row.TitlePrimary: Structure and wear properties of carbon implanted 304 stainless steel using plasma source ion implantation
z:row.Keyword: Stainless steel|Ion implantation|Carbon|Microstructure|Wear of materials|Mechanical properties|Plasma applications
z:row.Publisher: Publ by Elsevier Science Publ Co Inc, New York, NY, USA
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Methane plasma source ion implantation was used to implant carbon ions into 304 stainless steel. This paper examines the effects of high voltage pulse repetition rate on the structure and wear properties of implanted samples. The implantations were carried out at a target bias of -30 keV to a dose of 3 × 1017 atoms cm-2. Three repetition rates (42 Hz, 87 Hz and 126 Hz) were used. At low repetition rate, a carbon coated-implanted surface forms, while only an implanted surface is produced at high repetition rates. Metastable phases were observed and identified, and the microstructure at the surface was observed to be dependent on the chosen implantation parameters. Fe2C formed in the implantation layer which is produced at 42 Hz. Smaller size Fe2C and other forms of carbides (possibly Fe3C and/or (Cr, Fe)7C3) formed in samples implanted at 87 Hz. An increase in repetition rate to 126 Hz produced a shallower amorphous implantation layer. Possible explanations of phase formation mechanisms are given. Wear resistance of all the implanted samples was improved, with the coated-implanted sample produced at 42 Hz showing the greatest improvement. The mechanism of wear was observed to change from an adhesive mode to a mild abrasive mode after implantation.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Stainless steel type 304; Repetition rates; High voltage pulse; Metastable phases; Plasma source ion implantation

z:row.TitlePrimary: Irradiation behavior of bonded structures: impact of swelling-creep-stress relationship
z:row.TitleSecondary: Tenth Topical Meeting on the Technology of Fusion Energy, 7-11 June 1992
z:row.Keyword: austenitic stainless steel|composite materials|fusion reactor materials|irradiation induced creep|swelling
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Inst., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Radiation damage will be a major key point in the design of many duplex components in fusion reactors. There is a substantial amount of available data showing that stress plays a major role in the onset, and possibly the rate, of void growth in austenitic stainless steels. There is also a strong support for models which predict a coupling of swelling and creep through the stress environment. A parametric study for the stress-enhanced swelling and its connection to creep is conducted for a typical fusion power demonstration reactor
z:row.User2: irradiation behaviour; duplex structures; bonded structures; swelling-creep-stress relationship; fusion reactors; void growth; austenitic stainless steels; stress-enhanced swelling; creep; typical fusion power demonstration reactor

z:row.TitlePrimary: An improved first stability advanced fuel tokamak Apollo-L3
z:row.TitleSecondary: 14th IEEE/NPSS Symposium. Fusion Engineering. Proceedings (Cat. No.91CH30355-3), 30 Sept.-3 Oct. 1991
z:row.TitleTertiary: 14th IEEE/NPSS Symposium. Fusion Engineering. Proceedings (Cat. No.91CH30355-3)
z:row.Keyword: accidents|fusion reactor fuel|fusion reactor operation|fusion reactor safety|fusion reactor theory and design|plasma heating|plasma toroidal confinement
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Inst., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The Apollo-L3 conceptual reactor design utilizes D-3He fuel in a first stability tokamak configuration with direct conversion of synchrotron radiation to electricity as well as thermal conversion of surface heat and neutron energy. An update of the parameters of the design is given, and analyses of certain critical issues of Apollo-L3 are reported. These include plasma startup, loss of fast ions by magnetic ripple, safety analyses, and tritium storage. The update has led to an increase in the major radius by about 40 cm and an increase in the cost of electricity by about 10%. An alternative to direct energy conversion of the synchrotron radiation is to convert the energy using a thermal cycle; this increases the cost by another 10%. Startup of the plasma using a small amount of tritium eliminates the need for auxiliary heating other than that provided by the current drive system. Analysis of accident scenarios led to a possible offsite early dose of 3.6 rem for a LOCA without burning of the organic coolant and 103 rem if the organic coolant burns. On the basis of the expected temperature of the shield in a LOCA accident and the radioactive inventory, Apollo-L3 qualifies for a level of safety rating of one
z:row.User2: first stability advanced fuel tokamak; Apollo-L3; conceptual reactor design; fuel; direct conversion; synchrotron radiation; electricity; thermal conversion; surface heat; neutron energy; critical issues; plasma startup; loss; fast ions; magnetic ripple; safety analyses; storage; auxiliary heating; accident; offsite early dose; LOCA; burning; organic coolant; shield; radioactive inventory; safety rating; D-3He; T

z:row.TitlePrimary: Thermo-mechanical design and structural analysis of the first wall for ARIES-III, a 100 MWe D-3He power reactor
z:row.TitleSecondary: 14th IEEE/NPSS Symposium. Fusion Engineering. Proceedings (Cat. No.91CH30355-3), 30 Sept.-3 Oct. 1991
z:row.TitleTertiary: 14th IEEE/NPSS Symposium. Fusion Engineering. Proceedings (Cat. No.91CH30355-3)
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|fusion reactor theory and design|nuclear engineering computing
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Inst., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The ARIES-III first wall (FW) is made of a low-activation ferritic steel (MHT-9) and is cooled with an organic coolant (HB-40) at a pressure of 2 MPa. The FW has a coating of 0.01 cm tungsten on the MHT-9, followed by 0.15 cm of Be on the plasma side. This is needed for synchrotron radiation reflection and as a melt layer to guard against the thermal effects of a plasma disruption. Two-dimensional finite element models are used with the ANSYS computer code to determine both thermal stresses and temperature profiles. At the midplane, where the surface heating peaks at 1.86 MW/m2, the bulk coolant temperature is 385°C, the coolant velocity is 16 m/s, and the combined primary and secondary stresses are 350 MPa at a bulk steel temperature of 497°C. The maximum Be surface temperature facing the plasma is 571°C. It is shown that the ARIES-III FW can be relatively simple in design and can be made to meet the synchrotron reflectivity requirements and conform to all the design limitations, both thermal and structural
z:row.User2: thermo-mechanical design; structural analysis; first wall; ARIES-III; power reactor; low-activation ferritic steel; MHT-9; organic coolant; HB-40; coating; synchrotron radiation reflection; melt layer; thermal effects; plasma disruption; finite element models; ANSYS computer code; thermal stresses; temperature profiles; surface heating; bulk coolant temperature; secondary stresses; bulk steel temperature; design limitations; D-3He; Be; W

z:row.Abstract: Nitrogen ion implantation by Plasma Source Ion Implantation (PSII) was conducted on surgical Ti-6Al-4V alloy in different implanted conditions including variations in dose, ion energy and target temperature. The performance of the implanted alloy was characterized by measurements of wear behavior. Consideration of the wear results showed that the wear behavior is related to different failure criteria which should be determined after a careful failure analysis.

z:row.TitlePrimary: Wear modeling for nitrogen-implanted Ti-6Al-4V
z:row.Keyword: aluminium alloys|ion implantation|nitrogen|titanium alloys|vanadium alloys|wear
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: The wear resistance of ion-implanted Ti-6Al-4V test specimens was measured with a pin-on-disk wear tester. The samples were implanted by the plasma source ion implantation (PSII) technique using 50 keV nitrogen ions. Empirical models for both the wear depth and the wear lifetime were developed and the results were compared to unimplanted samples. PSII was shown to improve the wear resistance by factors of 20 to 55, depending on the applied load
z:row.User2: ion implantation; wear resistance; pin-on-disk wear tester; plasma source ion implantation; 50 keV; Ti-Al-V; Ti-Al-V-N

z:row.TitlePrimary: Analysis of singular stress fields in duplex fusion components
z:row.Keyword: Stresses -- Analysis|Nuclear Reactors, Fusion - Materials
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin - Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Thermal and swelling stress fields in bonded structures are sought using a model consisting of two thin, rectangular strips perfectly bonded along one surface. Existing results for stresses in the bulk, based on beam theory, are presented and their limitations are discussed. Plane elasticity is used to derive general solutions for the stress fields near the edge of the structure, in many cases yielding logarithmic or algebraic singularities. Methods for coupling these general edge fields to the stresses in the bulk are discussed, and the techniques are applied to materials and loading conditions relevant to fusion components. The impact of swelling and creep on both the order of the singularity and on its intensity is shown.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Bonded Structures

z:row.TitlePrimary: US aqueous salt blanket for ITER
z:row.Keyword: corrosion|electrolysis|fusion reactor materials|fusion reactor safety|fusion reactor theory and design|radiolysis
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Inst., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Aqueous lithium salt blankets have some very attractive features which make them likely candidates for use in the next generation of fusion devices such as ITER and beyond. The main attraction derives from the fact that such a blanket can go from a non-tritium-breeding state to a tritium breeding state by the simple dissolution of a lithium salt into the cooling water. Such a blanket is also relatively simple to design and analyze, and is amenable to accommodating penetrations. On the other hand, the salt solution raises concern with respect to radiolysis, electrolysis and corrosion, as well as safety issues related to them. The authors describe the design of the US entry of an aqueous salt blanket for ITER
z:row.User2: radiolysis; electrolysis; corrosion; safety; design; aqueous salt blanket; ITER; aqueous Li salt blanket

z:row.TitlePrimary: An aqueous lithium salt blanket for ITER
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings, IEEE Thirteenth Symposium on Fusion Engineering (Cat. No.89CH2820-9), 2-6 Oct. 1989
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings, IEEE Thirteenth Symposium on Fusion Engineering (Cat. No.89CH2820-9)
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|fusion reactor safety|lithium compounds|Tokamak devices
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Inst., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: An aqueous lithium salt blanket is designed as a candidate for the tritium production blanket of ITER (International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor). There are two rows of flat tube aqueous salt flow channels placed between beryllium blocks. The inboard and outboard blanket configurations have been optimized to maximize tritium breeding. A local outboard TBR (tritium breeding ratio) of 1.44 is obtained using LiOH at a concentration of 5 g/100 cm3. The overall TBR determined from 3-D neutronics calculations is 0.88. The aqueous-salt flow parameters have been optimized to minimize the salt pressure and inventory, leading to a pressure of 1.15 MPa and tritium inventory of 104 g. There are no crevices in the aqueous-salt channels, and a redundancy has been provided against a salt-to-water leak potential. The first wall, blanket, and shield qualify for shallow land burial. The highest temperature in the blanket after a two-week period without coolant is only 440°C. The first wall and blanket are capable of withstanding the worst disruption load
z:row.User2: aqueous lithium salt blanket; ITER; International Thermonuclear Experimental Reactor; flat tube aqueous salt flow channels; salt-to-water leak potential; shallow land burial; LiOH; T2 inventory

z:row.TitlePrimary: Energy conversion options for ARIES-III-a conceptual D-3He tokamak reactor
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings, IEEE Thirteenth Symposium on Fusion Engineering (Cat. No.89CH2820-9), 2-6 Oct. 1989
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings, IEEE Thirteenth Symposium on Fusion Engineering (Cat. No.89CH2820-9)
z:row.Keyword: direct energy conversion|fusion reactor theory and design|Tokamak devices
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: High-efficiency energy conversion schemes for a D-3He tokamak reactor are investigated. The loss channels for a D-3He plasma are through charged particles, neutrons, and radiation (synchrotron and bremsstrahlung), with only a few percent of the energy loss in neutrons. In contrast to D-T fusion reactors, this gives high leverage to energy-conversion methods which apply to charged particles or radiation. The ideas investigated focus on efficiently converting such energy to electricity or on converting thermal energy in ways which make effective use of fusion-reactor characteristics such as high magnetic fields. The energy-conversion methods investigated are given. Whether a concept was chosen for further study is indicated, as is the applicability of the concept to the three tokamak versions under consideration for the Advanced Reactor Innovation and Evaluation Study-III (ARIES-III): a high-field reactor (HFR), a second stability reactor (SSR), and a spherical torus (ST). Options not selected for further pursuit within the ARIES project are described briefly, and those selected are discussed more extensively. Selection criteria include cost, efficiency, technical feasibility, and how well a concept made use of fusion-specific features
z:row.User2: particle losses; radiation losses; ARIES-III; energy conversion schemes; loss channels; high magnetic fields; Advanced Reactor Innovation and Evaluation Study-III; high-field reactor; second stability reactor; spherical torus; cost; efficiency; D-3He tokamak

z:row.TitlePrimary: Apollo-L2, an advanced fuel tokamak reactor utilizing direct conversion
z:row.TitleSecondary: Proceedings, IEEE Thirteenth Symposium on Fusion Engineering (Cat. No.89CH2820-9), 2-6 Oct. 1989
z:row.TitleTertiary: Proceedings, IEEE Thirteenth Symposium on Fusion Engineering (Cat. No.89CH2820-9)
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor materials|fusion reactor theory and design|radiation effects|Tokamak devices
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Fusion Technol. Inst., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A scoping study of a tokamak reactor fueled by a D-3He plasma is presented. The Apollo D-3He tokamak incorporates recent advances in high-field magnets (20 T) and utilizes rectennas to convert the synchrotron radiation directly to electricity. The low neutron wall loading (0.1 MW/m2) permits a first wall lasting the life of the plant and enables the reactor to be classified as inherently safe. The cost of electricity is less than that from a similar power level D-T reactor. Technology considerations, including heat flux considerations, reference technology, and radiation damage to structural materials are discussed
z:row.User2: electricity cost; Apollo-L2; advanced fuel tokamak; direct conversion; scoping study; high-field magnets; rectennas; neutron wall loading; first wall; inherently safe; heat flux; reference technology; radiation damage; structural materials; 20 T; D-3He plasma

z:row.TitlePrimary: Apollo-an advanced fuel fusion power reactor for the 21st century
z:row.TitleSecondary: Eighth Topical Meeting on the Technology of Fusion Energy, 9-13 Oct. 1988
z:row.Keyword: fusion reactor theory and design|Tokamak devices
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Dept. of Nucl. Eng. & Eng. Phys., Wisconsin Univ., Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: A preconceptual design of a tokamak reactor fueled by a D-He-3 plasma is presented. A low aspect ratio (A=2-4) device is studied here but high aspect ratio devices (A>6) may also be quite attractive. The Apollo D-He-3 tokamak capitalizes on recent advances in high field magnets (20 T) and utilizes rectennas to convert the synchrotron radiation directly to electricity. The overall efficiency ranges from 37 to 52% depending on whether the bremsstrahlung energy is utilized. The low neutron wall loading (0.1 MW/m2) allows a permanent first wall to be designed and the low nuclear decay heat enables the reactor to be classed as inherently safe. The cost of electricity from Apollo is >40% lower than electricity from a similar sized DT reactor
z:row.User2: advanced fuel fusion power reactor; preconceptual design; tokamak reactor; low aspect ratio; high aspect ratio devices; Apollo; high field magnets; synchrotron radiation; D-3He fuelled reactor

z:row.TitlePrimary: Eigenfunction approach to singular thermal stresses in bonded strips
z:row.Keyword: Structural Analysis -- Stresses|Stresses--Thermal|Mathematical Techniques--Eigenvalues and Eigenfunctions|Surfaces--Bonding|Joints--Bonding
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Solutions for thermal stress singularities in finite bonded strips are sought by using an eigenfunction expansion in the neighborhood of the singularity. The coefficients in the resulting series are determined by satisfying the boundary conditions on surfaces far removed from the singularity either pointwise or in an integrated sense. The latter of these techniques is found to be more reliable. The accuracy of the solution is checked by comparing it to a semianalytical solution for thermal stresses in bonded quarter planes, which is derived by using the Mellin transformation. It is shown that the eigenfunction approach provides accurate solutions for the leading term in the series, thus capturing the essence of the thermal stress fields near the edge of the interface. The far-field solutions, however, are found to feature excessive inaccuracies, which are attributed to numerical errors.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Bonded Strips; Finite Bonded Strips; Mellin Transformation; Far-Field Solutions

z:row.TitlePrimary: Relaxation of thermal stress singularities in bonded viscoelastic quarter planes
z:row.Keyword: Stresses -- Thermal|Viscoelasticity
z:row.PeriodicalFull: Journal of Applied Mechanics, Transactions ASME
z:row.Author_Address_Affiliation: Univ of Wisconsin-Madison, Madison, WI, USA
z:row.Abstract: Singular thermal stress fields in bonded viscoelastic quarter planes are studied with the use of the viscoelastic analogy. The order of the singularity is shown to depend on the material properties, indicating that it will vary with time in viscoelastic materials. This is studied in detail for Maxwell materials, and it is shown that the order of the singularity generally increases with time. This evolution of the singularity can, for certain combinations of material properties, lead to initial increases in the stress levels near the edge of the interface before relaxation occurs.
z:row.Notes: Compilation and indexing terms, Copyright 2006 Elsevier Inc. All rights reserved
z:row.User2: Thermal Stress Singularities; Bonded Viscoelastic Quarter Planes; Maxwell Materials; Stress Relaxation
